feed.title: Movie Review: The Vow
feed.subtitle: Rachel McAdams loses her memory and Channing Tatum tries to find it. This is one Vow you'll soon forget.

content.div:
A car crash robs Paige (Rachel McAdams) of the last few years of her memories, leaving her husband (Channing Tatum) in the position of having to woo her all over again. The Vow has all the hallmarks of a Nicholas Sparks novel, but is in fact based on the true story of Kim and Krickitt Carpenter. Director Michael Sucsy keeps a surprisingly light hand on the material, which could have descended into eight kinds of mawkishness. Instead, it only hits about three.

Starring: Rachel McAdams, Channing Tatum and Sam Neill

Rating: Three stars out of five

Spare a moment of sympathy for the characters of Rachel McAdams. The petite Canadian can't seem to catch a break in her cinematic love life. In 2004's The Notebook, class and Alzheimer's kept her away from her true love, played by Ryan Gosling. More recently, she was The Time Traveler's Wife, and the spouse of another time-hopper, in Midnight in Paris. And don't get me started on her fate in Sherlock Holmes.

The Vow is stitched together from swatches of these other sad stories. A car crash robs her character, Paige, of the last few years of her memories. To her, it feels as though she has travelled in time, skipping over those years. Mentally, she's still in 2006 or so. Call it Groundhog Decade.

Losing five or six years might not matter so much to some people, but Paige seems to have reinvented herself during that time. She's astonished to learn that she's an artist and not a law student, an Obama supporter and not a Republican, a vegetarian and not an omnivore. She has a tattoo on her back. Oh, and she's married to Leo (Channing Tatum), whereas her last memory was being engaged to Jeremy (Scott Speedman).

Not to get too political, but on balance, this doesn't sound like a bad switch. Paige and Leo were clearly very much in love before the accident -- there's a pre-nup montage to prove it -- and he does his darndest to look after her afterward. Speedman is clearly not a good catch, signalled by the fact that he has the most obnoxious hair in the movie. Even so, Paige just doesn't feel any sparks with the now-stranger to whom she's wed.

The Vow has all the hallmarks of a Nicholas Sparks novel, but is in fact based on the true story of Kim and Krickitt Carpenter. Director Michael Sucsy, who won a Golden Globe and an Emmy for the 2009 TV movie, Grey Gardens, keeps a surprisingly light hand on the material, which could have descended into eight kinds of mawkishness. Instead, it only hits about three.

The biggest problem has to do with the changes in Paige's life during her "blank Paige" period. Sure, people modify their careers, eating habits, significant others, political affiliations and circle of friends, but all in the same go? Did she hit her head once before? The film trots out an explanation late in the game, but it feels contrived.

And is Tatum such a bad catch, even if sprung on you unawares? Hollywood doesn't think so; he's in at least four more films this year, including the recent Haywire and next month's 21 Jump Street.

On the plus side, McAdams does a fine job in a tricky role. It's easy enough for her to adopt a near-constant quizzical look at all the changes in her life. Much more difficult is to tie a knot of believable chemistry with her co-star and then undo it again; and, of course, to leave enough slack for a potential reconciliation, which is why everyone in the audience is hanging onto their Kleenex for.

Tatum has the easier job of remaining true to his wife, and occasionally huffing and puffing about how difficult she is making this for him. His attempts to re-woo the girl of his dreams are further complicated by her wealthy parents, played by Sam Neill and Jessica Lange as fantastically obtuse and dysfunctional. Although Paige hasn't spoken to them in years, they swoop in after the accident, anxious for their own chance at starting over with her.

There's a nice philosophical kernel at the centre of The Vow, touched on in voice-over by Tatum's character. If we are the sum of our memories, what does it do to our essence when some of those recollections are stripped away? Would we find a way to recreate those same reminiscences, or become someone new by doing something else? If the notion intrigues you but you can't stomach all the kissy-kissy scenes, wait for this summer's remake of Total Recall. For everyone else, The Vow is eminently watchable, though ultimately, just as forgettable.

entry.title: Top 10 Memory Loss Movies

link.Abstract: Inspired by The Vow, Here's a look at 10 other movies that feature forgetful characters.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: In The Vow, a young husband (Channing Tatum) tries to make his bride (Rachel McAdams) fall in love with him all over again after a serious car accident leaves her with severe memory loss. And while Mr. Tatum surely has a hard romantic hill to climb, he's certainly not the first to try to reach the apex of memory loss mountain. Here's a look at 10 other movies that feature forgetful characters.

link.title: Top 10 Ways To Get Rid of a Ghost

link.Abstract: We've picked 10 of our favourite survival movies. No guarantee you'll learn anything from them, but at least you won't risk losing an arm.
